problem_statement: The legacy code presents a classic example of

While the logic is functionally correct, the choice of data structures forces the CPU to do redundant work. The primary offender is queue.pop(0); in Python, lists are dynamic arrays, so removing the first item forces the interpreter to shift all remaining N−1N−1  items one slot to the left, resulting in O(N^2) complexity for the whole loop. The second bottleneck is output_buffer += line; since strings are immutable, Python allocates a new larger string and copies the old content over for every single line, another O(N^2) operation. Finally, checking if word in banned_words_list (where the list is not converted to a set) results in a linear scan for every single word in the text
